title: Smoking affects epigenetic ageing of lung bronchoalveolar lavage cells in Multiple Sclerosis
affiliations: Department of Clinical Neuroscience, Karolinska Institutet, Center for Molecular Medicine, Karolinska University Hospital, 171 76 Stockholm, Sweden
Department of Medicine, Solna, Karolinska Institutet, 171 76 Stockholm, Sweden
background: Cigarette smoking and lung inflammation are implicated in Multiple Sclerosis (MS) susceptibility and progression, and epigenetic age acceleration has been observed in blood and glial cells of pwMS.
hypotheses: Biological ageing in lung immune cells is affected by MS and smoking.
major_findings: Five epigenetic clocks showed significant differences between pwMS and HC, with four showing a smoking effect irrespective of MS status.
AltumAge clock revealed that, without smoking, pwMS BAL cells were epigenetically older than HC BAL cells, and smoking further affected epigenetic ageing in pwMS BAL cells.
Differential methylation of 114 AltumAge-CpGs was observed between pwMS smokers and non-smokers, affecting genes involved in innate immune processes.
These DNA methylation changes translated into transcriptional differences in BAL cells between pwMS smokers and non-smokers.
null_findings: Blood-derived monocytes did not show MS-specific or smoking-related AltumAge differences.
new_open_questions: The varying performance of epigenetic clocks in estimating DNAm age requires further investigation, potentially considering the distribution of distinct BAL myeloid cell types and other confounders.
The functional impact of the identified 114 AltumAge-CpGs and their associated genes on innate immune processes and cell motility in the context of MS and smoking needs further exploration.
sample_types: Human bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) cells, human blood monocytes
methods: DNA methylation analysis using eight DNA methylation-based clocks and two RNA-based clocks
Statistical analysis including MANCOVA, linear models, and gene ontology analysis
